document.heading: Authorization for Medical Consent for Children in the Care of Adults Other than Parents Temporary Amendment Act of 1992

history.narrative: Law 9-264, the “Authorization for Medical Consent for Children in the Care of Adults Other than Parents Temporary Amendment Act of 1992,” was introduced in Council and assigned Bill No. 9-752. The Bill was adopted on first and second readings on December 15, 1992, and January 5, 1993, respectively. Signed by the Mayor on January 26, 1993, it was assigned Act No. 9-412 and transmitted to both Houses of Congress for its review. D.C. Law 9-264 became effective on March 27, 1993.

BE IT ENACTED BY THE COUNCIL OF THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA, That this act may be cited as the "Authorization for Medical Consent for Children in the Care of Adults Other than Parents Temporary Amendment Act of 1992 See. 2. Title 16 of the District of Columbia Code is amended as follows a) The table of contents for the title is amended by adding the phrase "49. Authorization for Medical Consent for a Minor by an Adult Caregiver § 16-4901 b) A new Chapter 49 is added to read as follows § 16-4901. Authorization for medical consent for a minor by an adult caregiver a) A parent, legal guardian, or legal custodian may authorize an adult person, in whose care the child has been entrusted, to consent to any medical, surgical, dental, or mental health examination or treatment, including immunization, to be rendered to the minor under the supervision or upon the advice of a physician, nurse, dentist, or mental health professional licensed to practice in the District of Columbia, provided there is no prior order of any court in any jurisdiction currently in effect which would prohibit the parent, custodian, or guardian from exercising the power that they seek to convey to another person. Medical, surgical, and dental treatment or examination shall include any x-ray or anesthetic required for diagnosis or treatment b) Any written form that is signed by the parent, guardian, or custodian and notarized may be used to convey the authority described in subsection (a) of this section. The form below is offered as a sample only and its inclusion in this section shall not be construed to preclude the use of alternative language c) Any conveyance of authority described in subsection (a) of this section which is consistent with the requirements of subsection (b) of this section shall be honored by all health care facilities and practitioners described in subsection (e) of this section. Health care Note, Section 16-4704 Enrolled Original facilities and practitioners may honor conveyances of authority that do not meet the requirements of subsection (b) of this section. Notwithstanding subsection (g) of this section, the existence of a written document conveying any authority described in subsection (a) of this section which is consistent with the requirements of subsection (b) of this section creates a presumption that the authority has been lawfully conveyed d) Any conveyance of authority described in this section is revocable at will, unless otherwise agreed upon by the parent, guardian, or custodian and the person to whom authority is being conveyed. The parties may provide for terms in writing which would require the revocation to be in writing, make revocation effective only when a specified time period has elapsed after notification of intent to revoke, or any other terms that the parties deem appropriate e) A physician, surgeon, nurse, mental health professional, dentist, or other health care professional, or a hospital or medical facility, who or which relies on a written instrument that is consistent with the requirements of subsection (b) of this section and that authorizes another adult to consent to medical treatment of the executor’s minor child or ward shall not incur civil liability for treating a minor without legal consent if a reasonable and prudent health care professional would have relied on the written instrument under the same or similar circumstances f) This chapter is not intended to provide a substitute for protection proceedings conducted in the Family Division under Chapter 23 of this title g) The execution of-a document conveying any authority described in subsection (a) of this section shall not be binding in any future custody proceedings.
